name: Strom Thurmond
description: Governor, Dixiecrat presidential nominee, and long-serving senator whose 1948 revolt against civil rights foreshadowed the Southern Strategy.

timeline.event: Leaves the Democratic Convention over civil rights plank and runs as a States' Rights Democrat.
Filibusters the Civil Rights Act of 1957 for 24 hours and 18 minutes to block civil rights legislation.
Switches to the Republican Party after Lyndon Johnson signs the Civil Rights Act.

name: Jesse Helms
description: Television commentator turned senator who built a conservative base opposing school desegregation orders and civil rights enforcement.

timeline.event: Works as segregationist TV editorialist at WRAL, registered Democrat.
Delivers segregationist editorials on WRAL opposing the Civil Rights Act and Voting Rights Act.
Officially registers Republican; wins the Senate seat in 1972 as part of the GOP Southern surge.

name: Phil Gramm
description: Economist and congressman who aligned with Reagan's fiscal agenda, representing the later economic phase of realignment after the civil rights battles had been decided.

timeline.event: Elected to Congress as a Democrat representing a conservative Texas district.
Resigns after being removed from the House Budget Committee for collaborating with Reagan's White House.
Wins the same seat as a Republican and later serves as GOP senator.

name: Richard Shelby
description: Conservative Democrat who opposed much of the Clinton agenda and found a lasting home in the Republican caucus, illustrating the final stages of the realignment.

timeline.event: Elected to the U.S. Senate as a Democrat promising states' rights and limited federal reach.
Switches to the Republican Party the day after Republicans win control of Congress.
Chairs Senate committees as a Republican and campaigns against Democratic federal programs.
